content: How can I help you today?

I've been having a really hard time sleeping lately. There’s just so much stress going on, especially with work, and it’s keeping me up at night. My partner encouraged me to come here, but honestly, I’m not sure this will help.

It's understandable that work stress can weigh heavy and start affecting sleep—it sounds like it's been difficult to manage everything going on. It’s great that your partner wants to support you. What do you think has been the biggest factor contributing to the stress?

I’m worried about losing my job. Things at work haven’t been going well, and I feel like if the company decides to lay people off, I’ll be one of the first to go. I can’t stop thinking about how that would impact my family and our bills—it just spirals in my head at night.

It sounds like the fear of job loss and its potential impact on your family has been really weighing on you, especially during the quiet moments at night when your mind starts to spiral. Those worries must feel overwhelming at times. How have you been coping with these thoughts so far?

I usually just grab my phone and start scrolling. It helps distract me a bit, but then I end up staying up even later because I’m stuck on it. I know it’s not helping, but it’s hard to stop myself when my brain won’t quiet down.

It sounds like scrolling helps you take your mind off things temporarily, but it also keeps you up longer, which might make it even harder for you to feel rested. It’s tough to break that cycle when the stress feels constant. What do you think you need most right now to feel more in control of your nights?

I honestly don’t know. I feel like if I could somehow stop the racing thoughts or calm down at night, it might help, but I don’t know how to do that. My brain just won’t let go of everything that’s stressing me out.

Feeling stuck in those racing thoughts can be exhausting, especially when they keep coming back no matter how much you try to quiet them. It shows strength that you're open about wanting to find ways to calm down. When your mind races, do you notice anything—like certain worries or thoughts—that stand out the most?

It's mostly about work and how losing my job would affect my family. I feel like I'm letting them down, and that just adds to the weight of it all. It's like this constant loop in my head, and I can't break out of it.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot of pressure, not just about your work situation, but also about how it might affect your family. That sense of responsibility can make it hard to escape the loop of worry, especially when you care so deeply about them. Have you been able to share your feelings with your family or partner?

I’ve talked to my partner a bit, but I try not to share too much. I don’t want to worry them more than they already are. I feel like I need to hold it all together for everyone, but it’s getting harder to do that.

It seems like you’ve been trying to protect your partner and family by keeping a lot of your worries inside, even though it’s been hard on you. That shows how much you care for them, but it also sounds like it's adding to the weight you're carrying alone. How do you think your partner might respond if you opened up a little more about what you're feeling?
I think they’d try to reassure me, but I don’t want to burden them. They already have enough going on with the kids and everything else. I feel like it’s my job to handle this on my own.

It sounds like you’re trying to protect your partner while juggling so much on your own, which speaks volumes about how much you value taking care of them. At the same time, carrying all of this by yourself is making things heavier for you. What would it mean to you if sharing even a little of what you're feeling with your partner helped ease some of that weight?

I think it might help a bit. I just don’t know where to start or how much to say without making it seem like I’m not handling things. Maybe I should try, though—it’s just hard for me to lean on someone else.

It takes courage to even consider leaning on someone else, especially when you're used to carrying so much on your shoulders. Sharing a little bit might let your partner offer you some understanding or support without feeling like you're giving everything away. What’s one small thing you think you could say to them that feels manageable but still expresses how you're feeling?

Maybe I could tell them that I’ve been really stressed about work and that it’s been keeping me up at night. I think I could say that I’m trying to figure it out, but it’s just been a lot to handle. That way, they’d know what’s going on without worrying too much.

That sounds like a thoughtful way to share your feelings—letting them know about the stress you're carrying while showing you're actively working on figuring things out. It's a step toward opening up without feeling like you're adding to their worries. How do you feel about trying this approach soon?

I think I could give it a try. It might help to get it off my chest even just a little bit. I’ll try to find the right moment to bring it up. Thanks for helping me think through this—I guess it’s worth seeing how it goes.

It’s a big step to even consider opening up, and you’re showing a lot of bravery by being willing to try. Taking even that small step to share your feelings could make a difference for both you and your partner. You’re putting thought into how to approach it, which shows how much you care about handling it in a way that feels right. If you ever feel like you need more support or want to talk more, reaching out again can give you space to explore things further.
